yes, hudi by default uses gzip for parquet compression. but you can override the compression if need be.

@hehexiaoduantui : Is it that snapshot query works and you have having issues with incremental query? 
Were you able to run docker example given [here](https://hudi.apache.org/docs/docker_demo/#step-7-a-incremental-query-for-copy-on-write-table) w/o any issues to rule out any environmental specific issues?

Hudi maintains a timeline to track every commit/operation in hudi. This serves multiple purpose like transaction management, point in time query, incremental query etc. Let me know if you need more details.
@codope : Can you take this up please.

@zhedoubushishi : Can you take a look at this issue please? Feel free to create a jira and work on adding more documentation around dynamoDB locks. Or we can also think about writing a blog that covers end to end.
sure. Will be looking into github issues today and tomorrow.

@vingov the downloaded jar 0.10.0 is built against 3.1.x. it needs to be built against 3.0.x to work with it. There are some incompatibility with spark 3 versions. I'll make this section clearer https://hudi.apache.org/docs/next/quick-start-guide#setup

I haven't tried it out yet, but can you try 
`hoodie.hudi_read_test_4.consume.commit` instead of end.timestamp. 
CC @codope
It seems without compaction, these meta files would never be archived.

Setting the hoodie.store_visit_scan_hudi_read_test_4.consume.max.commits works!! Thanks @nsivabalan.
Just wanted to confirm how to interpret this config? 
In your example you have 4 commits in the below order.

20211228032849365
20211228033135331
20211228033152850
20211228033158272

If I have start.timestamp as 000 and max.commits as 2, the query will fetch the records as of commit - 20211228033135331

Really appreciate it if you are interested and help me review. Thanks in advance.

hi @zhangyue19921010  This pr is very good overall, thank you very much.

For 2nd point above, we can consider to combine the four or five configs to two, just `hoodie.database.name` and `hoodie.table.name`. If enable to sync to hive, the two configs represent `database` and `table` in metastore.
Currently, `hoodie.datasource.write.table.name`/`hoodie.table.name` is required. In this idea, only need to provide one more config `hoodie.database.name`, or `hoodie.datasource.write.database.name`, so that we can sync and mark a certain hudi table for query incrementally in hive.

> Query incrementally in hive need to set `hoodie.%s.consume.start.timestamp` which is used in `HoodieHiveUtils.readStartCommitTime`。Currently, we pass the `hoodie.table.name` named `tableName` to this function. We can add configs `hoodie.datasource.write.database.name` in `DataSourceWriteOptions` and `hoodie.database.name` in `HoodieTableConfig`. And if `database.name` provided, we joint the `database.name` and `table.name` and pass it to `readStartCommitTime`. And then, use can set `hoodie.dbName.tableName.consume.start.timestamp` in hive and query.
> 
> Also, `hoodie.datasource.write.database.name` and `hoodie.database.name` can reuse in other scene.

@xushiyan @YannByron   I probably understand the solution. 

SQL will persist the database name to ` hoodie.properties` by default, DF is selectively persisted through optional database parameters. Then, in incremental query, if  set ` databaseName.tableName`, we match `databaseName.tableName`. If it is inconsistent or there is no databaseName, incremental query will not be performed. If consistent, perform an incremental query.If the incremental query does not have a database name set, does not match the database name, only the table name
